concern:
Hello,
I’m really struggling to balance working full time and going to school with my full blown adhd. Does anyone have any advice because I’m convinced I’ll have to quit my full time job that I love to focus on school. I did one semester of school when I was 18 and dropped out because I wasn’t ready for it. I have the attention span of a squirrel and it seems  to have gotten worse since. 
TIA

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there, how are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm all ears.
I'm doing alright, but I've been feeling pretty overwhelmed lately with everything on my plate. I'd like to talk about some strategies for managing my daily challenges to stay on top of things.

It sounds like you're feeling stretched thin and in need of some tools to help you tackle your daily challenges. Let's start by exploring what's currently on your plate and what's been causing you to feel overwhelmed.

I'm currently juggling a fulltime job and my college coursework, which leaves me with very little downtime. My ADHD makes it especially tough to maintain focus and stay organized amidst all these demands.

That's a lot to handle! It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. Juggling a fulltime job and college coursework is challenging enough, but adding ADHD into the mix can make it even more difficult to stay on top of everything. It sounds like you're looking for strategies to help you manage your time, stay organized, and maintain focus.
I'm definitely feeling the strain from juggling my fulltime job and coursework with my ADHD. I'm hoping we can explore some practical strategies to help me improve my time management and focus.

Absolutely! There are several strategies we can discuss that might help you manage your time and focus more effectively. Let's start by exploring some time management techniques that can help you prioritize your tasks and make the most of the time you have. Have you tried using a planner or a digital calendar to keep track of your commitments and deadlines?

I've tried using a digital calendar before, but I often find it challenging to stick with it consistently. I'm open to exploring other techniques that might work better for me in managing my time and commitments.

One technique that might be helpful is breaking down larger tasks into smaller, more manageable chunks. For example, instead of setting a goal to finish my coursework, try breaking it down into smaller tasks like read one chapter of my textbook or complete one assignment. This can help make your tasks feel less overwhelming and easier to tackle.
I've tried breaking down tasks before, but I often lose momentum quickly due to my scattered focus. Could we discuss ways to build in reminders or rewards to help me stick with this approach?

Absolutely! One strategy that can be helpful for maintaining focus and motivation is to use the Pomodoro Technique. This involves setting a timer for a specific amount of time, usually 25 minutes, and working on a task until the timer goes off. Then, take a short break before starting another Pomodoro. You can also try rewarding yourself after completing a certain number of Pomodoros, such as taking a longer break or treating yourself to a snack.

I've heard about the Pomodoro Technique, but with my ADHD, I worry about staying motivated during those intervals. Could we brainstorm specific reward ideas that align with my busy schedule of work and school?

Absolutely! Here are some reward ideas that might work well for you

 Take a 10minute walk outside to clear your head and get some fresh air.
 Listen to a favorite song or podcast episode during your break.
 Enjoy a healthy snack, like a piece of fruit or a handful of nuts.
 Spend a few minutes browsing a website or social media account that you enjoy.
 Stretch or do some light exercise to help you stay energized and focused.

Remember, the key is to find rewards that are enjoyable and motivating for you, but that won't derail your progress or take up too much time.

I've got some good ideas from your suggestions, like taking a quick walk or listening to a favorite song, which could help me stay motivated without adding more stress to my packed schedule. Do you have any tips on how to incorporate these rewards seamlessly into my routine to maintain focus despite my ADHD?

Yes, here are some tips to help you incorporate rewards seamlessly into your routine

 Schedule your rewards into your daily plan For example, plan to take a walk after completing three Pomodoros, or listen to a song after finishing a chapter of your textbook.
 Keep your rewards small and frequent This can help you stay motivated and avoid feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of a larger reward that's further away.
 Make your rewards specific and concrete Instead of just saying I'll reward myself later, decide exactly what the reward will be and when you'll do it.
 Use visual reminders Consider setting a reminder on your phone or placing a sticky note on your computer screen to remind you of your reward.
 Be flexible If a reward isn't working for you, don't be afraid to try something else.

I appreciate these tips for incorporating rewards they seem like a practical way to combat my focus challenges with ADHD. Could we talk about how to adapt them specifically to my work and school routine without overwhelming my schedule?

Absolutely! Here are some ideas for adapting rewards to your work and school routine without adding too much extra time or stress

 During work breaks, take a quick walk outside or do some stretching at your desk.
 Listen to a favorite song or podcast episode during your commute to work or school.
 Reward yourself with a healthy snack or a few minutes of social media browsing during your lunch break.
 Take a short break after completing a task or assignment to do something enjoyable, like watching a funny video or chatting with a friend.
 Consider scheduling a longer reward, like watching an episode of your favorite TV show, for after a particularly busy or challenging day.

Remember, the goal is to find rewards that are enjoyable and motivating, but that won't add too much extra time or stress to your already busy schedule.

I like how these reward ideas fit into my work and school routine without adding extra pressure. Could we discuss ways to track my progress with them to make sure they help maintain my focus effectively?

Absolutely! Tracking your progress can be a great way to stay motivated and see the impact of your reward system. Here are some ideas for tracking your progress

 Use a journal or notebook to write down your daily goals and track your progress. You can also use this to reflect on what's working well and what might need to be adjusted.
 Use a habittracking app to monitor your progress and get reminders to stay on track.
 Keep a tally of how many Pomodoros you complete each day or week, and use this to track your progress over time.
 Consider setting weekly or monthly goals for yourself, such as completing a certain number of Pomodoros or finishing a specific task or assignment.
 Use a visual tracker, such as a chart or graph, to monitor your progress and see your improvements over time.

Remember, tracking your progress can be a great way to stay motivated and see the impact of your reward system. Find a method that works for you and that you'll be able to stick with consistently.

I think tracking my progress with a journal or app could help me stay motivated, but I'm worried it might add more to my already packed days. Could we brainstorm quick, simple methods that fit easily into my routine without overwhelming me?
